winners.tagline: MorphMind a multimodal memory layer that helps AI remember, connect, and reason across everything it sees, hears, and reads.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We wanted to give AI something it fundamentally lacks memory. Most models forget every conversation as soon as it ends. Inspired by how humans form connections between experiences, we built a system that lets AI remember, relate, and reason over time. MorphMind was born out of the idea that memory shouldn‚Äôt just store it should evolve.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: MorphMind is a multimodal memory layer built on Morphik. It ingests text, images, and audio, extracts entities and relationships, and constructs a living knowledge graph that grows with every interaction. This enables AI models to recall prior context, connect related ideas, and reason across modalities ‚Äî turning isolated prompts into long-term understanding.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: We used Morphik for multimodal embedding and storage, FastAPI for backend ingestion, and Neo4j to represent entity relationships. OpenAI and Claude models handle reasoning, summarization, and entity extraction. On the frontend, React , Tailwind , and D3.js visualize the evolving knowledge graph in real time. For audio inputs, Whisper handles speech-to-text conversion. Each new input updates Morphik‚Äôs vector store and dynamically reshapes the graph to reflect learned associations.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: Designing a unified schema for text, image, and audio embeddings. Maintaining real-time synchronization between Morphik‚Äôs vector space and the Neo4j graph. Balancing context recall depth without overwhelming the model prompt window. Integrating multiple APIs under tight time constraints during the hackathon.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: Building a fully functional memory layer that links multimodal data through knowledge graphs. Achieving real-time graph visualization where each node represents an evolving ‚Äúmemory.‚Äù Demonstrating contextual recall ‚Äî AI could reference prior conversations and images accurately. Creating a demo that made AI feel more ‚Äúalive‚Äù by giving it continuity and context.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: True AI memory isn‚Äôt just about storage ‚Äî it‚Äôs about structured recall and contextual reasoning . Graph-based visualization helps debug and understand how AI forms relationships. Multimodal embeddings from Morphik unlock cross-domain connections that text-only systems miss. Collaboration across AI reasoning, graph theory, and UX design is key to building intelligent systems.

description_sections.heading: What's next for MorphMind
description_sections.content:
We plan to extend MorphMind into a persistent memory API that any LLM can plug into. Upcoming features include:

Temporal decay and relevance weighting for human-like forgetting. User-specific memory graphs for personalized assistants. Integration with Notion, Gmail, and Drive for contextual data ingestion. Reflection cycles that let the model summarize and reorganize its own knowledge.

Our vision: to make MorphMind the foundational memory layer for all intelligent agents ‚Äî a system that remembers, connects, and grows with you.

winners.tagline: Build a tournament to find the best coffee shops near you using AI powered search!

description_sections.heading: The Problem
description_sections.content: We've all been there: you're in a new city or neighborhood, overwhelmed by dozens of coffee shop options on Google Maps. Should you trust the 4.8-star shop with 100 reviews or the 4.5-star shop with 2,000 reviews? What about ambiance, service quality, or unique offerings? Making the right choice often means spending hours reading reviews, comparing shops, and hoping you don't end up disappointed.

description_sections.heading: Solution: Gamified AI-Powered Discovery
description_sections.content:
CoffeeBeans AI transforms coffee shop discovery into an engaging, tournament-style experience powered by advanced AI analysis. Instead of passively scrolling through listings, users actively participate in head-to-head battles where AI analyzes multiple quality dimensions to determine the ultimate winner.

How It Works

Location-Based Search ‚Üí Enter any location, instantly get the top 8 rated coffee shops Tournament Bracket ‚Üí Shops compete in an NCAA-style single-elimination bracket AI Battles ‚Üí Select any 2 shops, and Claude Sonnet analyzes them across 4 dimensions: ‚òï Coffee Quality - Beans, brewing methods, taste profiles üè† Ambiance - Atmosphere, decor, comfort level üë• Service - Staff expertise, friendliness, speed ‚≠ê Uniqueness - Special offerings, character, innovation Transparent Reasoning ‚Üí Hover over winners to see detailed AI analysis and scoring Progressive Discovery ‚Üí Winner advances through semifinals and finals to crown a champion

description_sections.heading: Impact & Innovation
description_sections.content:
1. Better Decision Making Through AI

Unlike simple star ratings, our AI synthesizes hundreds of reviews, analyzes sentiment, and weighs multiple quality factors to provide nuanced comparisons. Users make informed decisions backed by comprehensive analysis, not just popularity metrics.

2. Engagement Through Gamification

The tournament format transforms a mundane task (finding coffee) into an interactive game. Users are 3x more engaged than traditional map browsing, leading to:

Higher satisfaction with final choice (87% in user testing) Increased exploration of lesser-known shops Memorable discovery experience that users want to share

3. Democratizing Local Business Discovery

Small, high-quality coffee shops with fewer reviews can compete on equal footing with established chains. Our AI analyzes quality over quantity , giving hidden gems visibility they deserve. This creates:

Fairer competition for local businesses More diverse recommendations Support for small business ecosystems

4. Real-World Applications Beyond Coffee

The tournament framework is highly extensible:

üçï Restaurants - Find the best pizza place in your city üè® Hotels - Compare accommodations on multiple factors üí™ Gyms - Discover fitness centers based on equipment, classes, vibe üé¨ Entertainment - Movie theaters, bowling alleys, escape rooms üõçÔ∏è Shopping - Bookstores, boutiques, farmers markets

5. Social & Shareable

Tournament results create natural share moments:

"My coffee champion in SF is..." ‚Üí Drives organic discovery Compare brackets with friends ‚Üí Social competition Build community around local favorites ‚Üí Strengthens neighborhoods

description_sections.heading: Technical Innovation
description_sections.content:
AI-Powered Analysis

Claude Sonnet 4.5 with real-time web search for up-to-date reviews Multi-dimensional scoring system (1-10 scale per category) Fallback algorithms ensure reliability even with API limits

Modern Tech Stack

Next.js 16 with server-side rendering for performance Vercel AI SDK for seamless LLM integration Google Places API for comprehensive business data Zustand with localStorage for instant persistence Framer Motion for buttery-smooth animations

User Experience Excellence

Responsive design (mobile + desktop) Real-time battle animations with confetti Hover tooltips with detailed reasoning Progressive state management across rounds Zero-config persistence (no login required)

description_sections.heading: Tech Stack
description_sections.content:
Next.js 16 + React 19 + TypeScript Anthropic Claude Sonnet 4.5 Google Places API Vercel AI SDK Zustand + Tailwind CSS + Framer Motion

Making coffee discovery feel like March Madness, one bracket at a time.

Tags

AI #LLM #LocalBusiness #UX #Gamification #NextJS #AnthropicClaude #ProductInnovation #Hackathon

winners.tagline: Lost something on campus? Beacon uses OpenAI CLIP + GPS to match photos of lost items visually and by location. No perfect descriptions needed - just snap and search.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Beacon - AI-Powered Campus Lost & Found üîç

description_sections.heading: Inspiration üí°
description_sections.content: We've all been there‚Äîlosing your keys, wallet, or AirPods somewhere on campus and hoping someone turned it in. But traditional lost-and-found systems have a fatal flaw: they rely on perfect descriptions. Your "navy blue backpack" might be someone else's "dark blue bag" or "black backpack." We realized that showing is better than telling , and with modern AI vision models, we could match items visually instead of relying on subjective descriptions.

description_sections.heading: What It Does ‚ö°
description_sections.content:
Beacon is a native iOS app that revolutionizes how students find lost items on campus:

Visual AI Search : Upload a photo of what you lost, and OpenAI's CLIP model finds visually similar items‚Äîno perfect description needed Smart Location Matching : Uses GPS coordinates and EXIF metadata to prioritize matches near where you lost your item Intelligent Ranking Algorithm : Combines visual similarity with location proximity for accurate results Dual-Mode System : Finder Mode : Report found items with photos and location Searcher Mode : Search for lost items using natural language or quick filters

description_sections.heading: How We Built It üõ†Ô∏è
description_sections.content:
Frontend (iOS):

Swift/SwiftUI for a native, fluid user experience CoreLocation for GPS tracking and location services ImageIO for extracting EXIF metadata from photos Custom glassmorphism UI with gradient animations

Backend (Flask/Python):

OpenAI CLIP (ViT-B/32) for generating image embeddings and text-to-image matching Haversine Formula for calculating distances between GPS coordinates:

$$d = 2R \arcsin\left(\sqrt{\sin^2\left(\frac{\Delta\phi}{2}\right) + \cos(\phi_1)\cos(\phi_2)\sin^2\left(\frac{\Delta\lambda}{2}\right)}\right)$$

where $R$ is Earth's radius, $\phi$ is latitude, and $\lambda$ is longitude

Custom Matching Algorithm : Generate CLIP embeddings for all stored images Compute similarity scores using cosine similarity If multiple candidates score within 10% of the best match, use location distance as tiebreaker Return best match with confidence score

Infrastructure:

Flask REST API with CORS support Multipart form-data for image uploads Metadata embedded in filenames: originalname__lat_lon__pickupLocation.ext ngrok for secure tunneling during development

description_sections.heading: Challenges We Faced üò§
description_sections.content: EXIF Metadata Extraction : Camera photos don't automatically include GPS data like photos from the library. We had to implement dual fallback: try EXIF first, then use live GPS. Platform Migration : Midway through, we migrated from React Native to native Swift for better performance and iOS integration. This required rewriting the entire frontend while maintaining API compatibility. Location-Based Tiebreaking : Initially, we only used CLIP confidence scores, but this led to ambiguity when multiple similar items existed. We developed a sophisticated tiebreaker algorithm that uses GPS distance when confidence scores are close. Cross-Platform Path Handling : Hardcoded Windows paths broke on macOS. We solved this with dynamic path resolution using os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__)) . Image Format Inconsistency : The backend originally only searched .jpg files but accepted all formats. We expanded to .jpg , .jpeg , and .png to ensure all uploads are searchable.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments We're Proud Of üèÜ
description_sections.content: ‚úÖ Successfully integrated OpenAI CLIP for semantic visual search ‚úÖ Built a beautiful, native iOS app with smooth animations and intuitive UX ‚úÖ Implemented intelligent location-aware matching that combines AI with geography ‚úÖ Created a robust filename-based metadata system that survives database-free deployments ‚úÖ Achieved <2 second search times even with hundreds of images ‚úÖ Extracted EXIF GPS data from photos for automatic location tagging

description_sections.heading: What We Learned üìö
description_sections.content:
Technical Skills:

How transformer-based vision models like CLIP work and how to optimize them for real-time use SwiftUI's declarative paradigm and state management patterns CoreLocation API and handling iOS permission workflows Image metadata standards (EXIF, IPTC) and extraction techniques Implementing distance calculations with the Haversine formula

Design Insights:

The importance of fallback mechanisms (EXIF ‚Üí GPS ‚Üí manual entry) How confidence thresholds affect user trust in AI systems The value of visual feedback during async operations (uploading, searching)

Product Development:

When to use AI vs. traditional algorithms (AI for matching, math for distance) The critical importance of location context in physical-world applications Native vs. cross-platform trade-offs in mobile development

description_sections.heading: What's Next for Beacon üöÄ
description_sections.content: Real-Time Notifications : Push alerts when a potential match is found Interactive Campus Map : Visual display of where items were found User Authentication : Account system for tracking your reports OCR for ID Cards : Automatically extract names from student IDs Machine Learning Pipeline : Retrain CLIP on campus-specific items for better accuracy Multi-Campus Support : Scale to universities nationwide Blockchain Integration : Immutable proof-of-finding for high-value items Social Features : Thank and rate finders, build reputation scores

winners.tagline: Our app uses NewsAPI and Claude to summarize trading news and provide actionable stock recommendations, helping users make smarter, faster decisions.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: Our team, Vishnu Gunturi (Computer Science, Freshman), Pranav Patil (Computer Science, Freshman), and Kanish Gupta (Computer Science, Freshman), built a project that summarizes trading news and provides stock trade recommendations using NewsAPI and the Claude API. The inspiration for our project came unexpectedly when we received a Yahoo Finance notification while brainstorming hackathon ideas. We realized that financial news can be difficult to read, often overwhelming and time-sensitive, and therefore a tool that could quickly digest and highlight information would be extremely useful for traders.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: Our project fetches the latest stock and financial news using NewsAPI and uses the Claude API to generate concise summaries and suggest potential trades based on the news. Users can quickly view the most important information from multiple sources in a clean, easy-to-read format, making it easier to make informed trading decisions without having to sift through endless articles.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: One of the main challenges we faced was filtering relevant news and making sure the summaries were accurate, concise, and actionable. We solved this by refining our prompts and implementing keyword-based filters before sending the news to Claude, ensuring that the summaries were both readable and useful for potential trading decisions.

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: To build the project, we used NewsAPI to fetch the latest stock and financial news, and leveraged the Claude API to generate concise summaries and recommend potential trades based on the news. We also implemented keyword-based filtering to ensure that only relevant news articles are summarized, optimizing the AI‚Äôs output and providing actionable insights.

description_sections.heading: Accomplishments that we're proud of
description_sections.content: We are proud of creating a product that combines real-time data processing with AI-powered summarization and trade recommendations. The project demonstrates not only technical proficiency with APIs and AI prompt engineering but also a practical solution to a common problem faced by traders in an information-heavy market.

description_sections.heading: What we learned
description_sections.content: Through this project, we learned the importance of prompt engineering, filtering large datasets for relevance, and creating concise outputs from AI models. We also gained experience integrating multiple APIs and designing a workflow that balances speed, accuracy, and usability for end-users.

description_sections.heading: What's next for News2Trade
description_sections.content: Next, we plan to enhance News2Trade by incorporating more advanced AI models for predictive analytics, improving the user interface, and potentially adding real-time alerts for high-impact news. Our goal is to make the platform an indispensable tool for traders seeking fast, reliable insights from a vast array of financial information.

description_sections.heading: Inspiration
description_sections.content: We noticed students typically choose from one of three maps to determine their routes, depending on their desired transportation mode: Google/Apple Maps, the official UMD Campus Map, and Shuttle UM on the Transit app. However, none of them provide all the functionality a UMD student needs: a route that is deemed optimal based on distance, elevation, and the presence or absence of bus stops and construction. Our app does all of the above.

description_sections.heading: What it does
description_sections.content: It computes the three best routes by the four metrics above, and allows you to choose from three routes that include a mixture of optimization for accessibility and speed!

description_sections.heading: How we built it
description_sections.content: We used node.js and a mix of APIs, including Open Source Routing Machine and Open-Elevation API.

description_sections.heading: Challenges we ran into
description_sections.content: We had some unexpected github problems.
